title: 108_s2511
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004". It includes definitions related to the Chimayo Water Supply System. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a feasibility study for a water supply system in the Santa Cruz River Valley, specifically for the town of Chimayo, New Mexico. The study will explore options for connecting to water sources and operating in conjunction with the Espanola Water Filtration Facility. The Secretary will conduct a study for a water supply system in Chimayo, New Mexico, considering various water sources, reuse options, and lifecycle costs. The study must be completed within 3 years, with a 75% Federal cost share. Coordination of activities is required. The Secretary will coordinate with relevant agencies to conduct a study on water supply in Chimayo, New Mexico, with a 75% Federal cost share. A report must be submitted to Congress within 1 year of completion or 4 years after enactment of the Act. Emergency water supply development assistance contracts may be entered into with water authorities in the study area. SEC. 103. EMERGENCY WATER SUPPLY DEVELOPMENT ASSISTANCE: The Secretary may provide assistance for activities such as hauling water, installing purification technology, drilling wells, and more, with a 75% Federal cost share. SEC. 104 authorizes appropriations for sections 102 and 103, allocating $2,000,000 for fiscal years 2005-2008 for section 102 and $3,000,000 for fiscal years 2005-2010 for section 103. Amounts under subsection (a)(1) cannot be used for water infrastructure construction. The Secretary will provide financial assistance for the construction of the Espanola water filtration facility in New Mexico, including various projects to meet future water demands in the region. The Secretary will provide financial assistance for the construction of water facilities in New Mexico, including filtration facilities, water storage, pump stations, and transmission lines. The project aims to use reclaimed water to enhance water resources and supplies. The Federal share of the total cost will not exceed 25%, and funds cannot be used for operation or maintenance. Authorization of $3,000,000 for facility construction from 2005 to 2009.
